items.question: What is video conferencing?
items.answer: Video conferencing is a type of virtual, online meeting where two or more people talk through a video and audio call in real-time.

items.answer: Voice over Internet Protocol, or VoIP, is an internet-based technology that uses a broadband connection.

items.question: What equipment do I need for video conferencing?
items.answer: If using a computer, you need to have a video monitor, webcam (most laptops have one built-in), microphone (some exterior webcams come with a microphone included) and exterior speakers. If using a cellphone, most of what you need is built into the cellphone already, although earbuds might be a good option to hear things better and to block out outside noises if you’re having the video call in a public location.

items.question: What are some security measures to take when using a video conferencing platform?
items.answer: There are several ways to enhance the security of whichever video conferencing  platform you choose. These include creating unique meeting IDs and passwords for each gathering, having someone allow attendees into the meeting rather than everyone gathering all at once, restricting who can give out meeting invitations and limiting on-screen sharing and access to documents when screen sharing.

items.question: What is Zoom?
items.answer: Zoom is a teleconferencing service that allows for users to hold audio or video calls. It also has a series of options that allow for conferences of up to 1,000 people. Limited free calls lower the barrier to using the service for new customers.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer

meta_url.path: › home  › articles  › zoom vs. skype — full comparison

items.question: What is Skype?
items.answer: Skype is another service that allows users to make audio or visual calls. It uses subscriptions plans in terms of pricing, has no free option, and offers much more limited business features.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer

items.question: What is better Skype or Zoom?
items.answer: In many ways, the services are the same: Both offer similar basic features and have the same quality of calls. However, the robust array of features used by Zoom – as well as the free uses and pricing advantages – put it in a better spot over Skype.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer

meta_url.path: › home  › articles  › zoom vs. skype — full comparison

items.question: Why are people using Zoom instead of Skype?
items.answer: There are at least two reasons for this. First, Zoom has different and broader features than Skype, like the ability to put participants in different breakout rooms. Second, Zoom has many free options that Skype simply doesn’t have. Zoom has also benefited from superior marketing and a massive uptick in use – particularly during the worst of the COVID-19 pandemic.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer

meta_url.path: › home  › articles  › zoom vs. skype — full comparison

items.question: What's the difference between Zoom vs Skype?
items.answer: There are two primary differences between Zoom and Skype, with both coming back to the same basic principle: Skype is a far more basic service. It offers cheap rates for international calls, and in many cases, these calls are cheaper if an individual is looking to have an international call. However, Zoom offers more features, has more mass-conferencing abilities, offers more features, and has free options that can be used for families. Skype simply lacks many of these features, and this puts the service at a competitive disadvantage.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer

meta_url.path: › home  › articles  › zoom vs. skype — full comparison

items.question: Is Zoom or Skype better for personal use?
items.answer: When it comes to use for personal or for family uses, there is more of a level playing field. In many cases, users simply will not need the robust array of features that Zoom offers, since it is unlikely that individuals will want to leave a breakout room for a chat with their cousins or need more than 1,000 people to attend the Zoom meeting. However, Zoom still holds an advantage for one key reason: Pricing. Zoom calls of up to forty minutes are free, and Skype does not offer such an option. This makes it preferable.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer

meta_url.path: › home  › articles  › zoom vs. skype — full comparison

items.question: Why is Zoom more popular than Skype?
items.answer: In addition to all of the reasons noted above, Zoom’s market growth simply soared over Skype’s during the COVID pandemic. Businesses, of course, were forced to switch to virtual and electronic communication. Zoom offered these options and allowed for many conferences to be switched and held virtually. This helped to make the service far more popular than Skype.
items.title: Zoom vs. Skype — Full Comparison - History-Computer
